data.title: Network drives do now show up when running Atom as administrator.
data.body: When running Atom as an administrator on windows you are unable to scope to network drives when opening a file.

data.title: Release notes don't seem to update properly
data.body:
I use Atom on two different machines and I'm seeing anomalies when looking at the release notes. On one of my machines the release notes are always blank with only a button showing to view previous release notes. On the other machine the release notes are old. Here is a current screenshot but keep in mind this isn't the only time the release notes have been outdated compared to the release I was using.

Currently using Atom 0.136 on Windows 8.1 (on two different systems).

![atom-release-notes-problem](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/190154/4561202/e6b3c3f4-4efa-11e4-917c-87407b1d7419.png)

data.title: Selection::insertText: undo skip doesn't work
data.body:
The [documentation](https://atom.io/docs/api/v0.136.0/Selection#instance-insertText) says:

> .undo
> if skip, skips the undo stack for this operation.

but it doesn't work.

I looked into the source code. The [only line](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/v0.136.0/src/selection.coffee#L362), which does anything with `undo`, is:

```
newBufferRange = @editor.buffer.setTextInRange(oldBufferRange, text, pick(options, 'undo'))
```

In [`setTextInRange`](https://github.com/atom/text-buffer/blob/v3.2.8/src/text-buffer.coffee#L512), the `undo` option becomes `normalizeLineEndings` (default: `true`). It looks like `normalizeLineEndings` has nothing to do with undo.

This means the `undo` option gets interpreted as something totally unrelated to undo.

data.title: Popover-list styleclass not working
data.body:
I'm trying to display a SelectListView inline, next to the cursor. The correct styleclass seems to be popover-list. Unfortunately it doesn't work.
The View does not display at all - it becomes invisible.
Using overlay and from-top the List is displayed - but at the top. I would like to inline it.

I'm rather sure that this is not a problem with my code. The View does display, just not with the styleclasses I need.

Here are detailed descriptions:
https://discuss.atom.io/t/how-to-position-selectlistview-inline/12500
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/26236205/atom-editor-display-selectlistview-inline

data.title: focus pane on direction broken
data.body:
When I try to use focus pane above/below/right or left I get the following error:

```
Uncaught TypeError: undefined is not a function /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/workspace-element.js:202
addCommands.window:focus-pane-on-right /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/workspace-element.js:202
(anonymous function) /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/workspace-element.js:91
jQuery.event.dispatch /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:4676
elemData.handle /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:4360
module.exports.KeymapManager.dispatchCommandEvent /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:544
module.exports.KeymapManager.handleKeyboardEvent /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:386
module.exports.WindowEventHandler.onKeydown /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/window-event-handler.js:151
```

At first I thought I broke something with my config/packages. But even when I remove the .atom directory and restart atom I get this error. Focus next/previous pane still works though.

Using version 0.136.0 on os X

data.title: Windows: EPERM error when typing / in any file
data.body:
I am getting following error when trying to write some comments in my JS files starting with //

error:

```
Uncaught Error: EPERM, operation not permitted 'z:\System Volume Information'  fs.js:1
```

Later I noticed that this error occurs when I start to type back slashes as "/" in any type of file.

data.title: API for creating views in packages
data.body:
If we plan to deprecate the space pen `View` class, we need a story for what folks can move to. Some kind of system that interoperates with custom elements. Something that UI heavy packages like settings view and fnr can use. 
- Maybe it looks like space pen (space-pencil)?
- Maybe it's react?

We need to do more thinking.

data.title: Think about how to scope settings to a single file / dir
data.body:
This is a data gathering issue. 
- Does we need to be able to scope settings per file?
- Will the API need to change? Or can we do it within the bounds of the new scoped settings?

In the directory case, we could use a `.atom` file. 

For the file case, @kevinsawicki had the idea yesterday to basically have a `.atom` file for any file needing specific settings. eg. `some-file.coffee` would have `some-file.coffee.atom`.

data.title: :lipstick: Remove unnecessary conditional
data.body: `mkdir -p` is an idempotent operation.

data.title: Add overlay decorations to text editor API
data.body:
Encouraging access to the model layer instead of the view layer has been a central theme in our changes to Atom's API for 1.0. While our current decorations API eliminates the need to access the view layer in order to render highlights, view layer access is still required to implement custom overlays such as the autocomplete menu. Since we'll be pushing the editors internals into the shadow DOM, we need to provide a model-level alternative.

A natural way to do this is to extend the current decoration API with a new kind of decoration in addition to highlights, an _overlay decoration_. Like the pane item and panel APIs, package authors should be able to associate a view model or view with a marker and have it render in the editor in the right place. Here's how I envision the it looking:

``` coffee
decoration = textEditor.decorateMarker marker,
  type: 'overlay'
  item: new AutocompleteMenu
```

Just like for pane and panel items, you'll be able to employ the workspace's view provider system to teach Atom how to render views for item models:

``` coffee
atom.workspace.addViewProvider
  modelConstructor: AutocompleteMenu
  viewConstructor: AutocompleteMenuElement
```

This means you can use `atom.workspace.getView()` to retrieve the view for an overlay decoration's item.

``` coffee
atom.workspace.getView(decoration.getItem()) # ==> get corresponding view
```

If your overlay is simple enough to implement without a model, you can also add a view directly as an item rather than using the view provider system for sake of convenience.

``` coffee
element = new AutocompleteMenuElement
element.setModel(new AutocompleteMenu)

decoration = textEditor.decorateMarker marker,
  type: 'overlay'
  item: element
```

data.title: Use custom tag names in core
data.body: I was previously considering this part of the shadow DOM roadmap item, but I think it makes sense to be a bit more granular. This issue covers conversion of all the custom elements in core to use custom tag names. We can preserve their existing classes for now, so it should be a simple change.

data.title: Document sort params on atom.io package list
Snippets should be displayed in autocomplete
data.body:
I'm using Atom V0.135.0 for web development. When working in a HTML file, I wrote `ta` and pressed `ctrl+space` hoping to autocomplete it to `table`. I was surprised to see no `table` in autocomplete suggestion. My initial thought was that Atom does not support HTML autocompletes and I was very disappointed. But I could not believe Atom missed such a basic functionality. So I digged deeper. I found that atom has HTML _snippets_ which can be used by writing `ta` and pressing `tab` key to use the `table` snippet.

This behavior is very counter intuitive. Behind the scenes, I do not care if it's implemented as _autocomplete_ or _snippet_, but when I write a half-word and press the _autocomplete_ key combination, I expect everything to be displayed there as a suggestion, even the snippets. What do the devs think about it?

data.title: Use package.json engine field to prevent package update or installation
data.body:
This feature spans several package/repo (apm, settings-view, atom), so I'll put it there as reference. 
### Use Case

I created a package on Atom version X and relied on some API that was broken on version Y. If I fix the package to use the new API, people that still use version X will be notified of the update and will end up with errors due to the new API not being available in their current version. 
One solution packages-side would be to detect which API is available and switch between implementation. But as you can guess, this is far from ideal as it puts a lots of constraints in maintaining such a package.
### A Simple Solution

Atom is already assuming that every package must define an `engine` field with an Atom semver string as value. A simple solution would be to test this version against the current Atom version. 
This test could be done at several moments: 
- When loading a package in Atom, for instance, a package sets its engine version to `<= 0.123`, if Atom version is `0.124` the package is not loaded and reported as an incompatible package.
- When installing a package with `apm install <package>`. If the package engine version doesn't match the current Atom version, the install is cancelled and reported to the user with the adhoc message (package X expects version Y of Atom).
- When searching/installing/updating a package from the settings view, the package block could display mention of the expected engine version, and the install/update button should be disabled if the versions doesn't match.

That way, people with legacy versions of Atom won't see errors poping up due to a package update relying on new API not available in their version while, at the same time, providing them with information about the incompatibility

data.title: Fix join lines so that only a single space will exist between two lines
Squirrel for Windows: Delta Packages
data.body: This PR enables Squirrel delta packages, which basically consists of downloading the previous versions so that we can build deltas based on them. This PR also bumps the Squirrel version to 0.5.3 (since `SyncGitHubReleases` is part of Squirrel and version skew would be weird)

data.title: Adjust font size using Control key with Mouse Scroll Wheel.
data.body:
Following from previous [PR](https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/3475), to allow merging.

This Pull Request adjusts the font size when the control key is held down and scroll wheel is used.

It ignores OSX(darwin) as this platform has a conflicting accessibility feature which should not be overwritten.

Mac OS X 10.9.5

data.title: Convert text editor to custom element
data.body:
Closes #3732

This PR builds on #3734 to implement commands properly, so they should be merged in order.

data.title: Make command registry backward compatible with jQuery::on and ::trigger
data.body:
Closes #3731

This PR applies some surgical patching to jQuery so that commands registered with `atom.commands.add` integrate smoothly with jQuery event handlers registered with `$::on` and `$::command`. Now a jQuery handler can stop propagation to a command registry handler and vice-versa.

data.title: Convert text editor to custom element
data.body:
Status: Ready to merge a PR (#3735) after command registry backward compatibility (#3734).

This was originally part of #3677, but I think it makes sense to break it out as its own task. This is almost completed on a [branch](https://github.com/atom/atom/compare/ns-text-editor-custom-element), but is blocked on so we can use atom.commands for implementing the custom element's commands.

data.title: Make command registry backward compatible
data.body:
Status: Ready to merge PR #3734. Would like a live-code review.

Commands registered via `atom.commands` don't cleanly integrate with commands registered via `$::command`. Currently, command registry commands are dispatched first completely independent of jQuery commands. This prevents commands registered via one mechanism from preempting commands registered via the other.

data.title: Issue when adding values to HTML code embedded in a multi-line JS variable
data.body:
To duplicate write the following JS: ``` js jQuery( document ).ready( function(){ form_code= '' + '
    ' + '
  • ' + '
    ' + ' ' + ' ' + '
    ' + '
    • ' + '
' ; jQuery( 'a[href="#login"]' ).html( jQuery( 'a[href="#login"]' ).html() + form_code ); } ); ``` Now, try and add a class to `ul.sub-menu li.menu-item` by typing it in the editor. Make sure **JavaScript** is your file type.
